sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: Vi is the first full screen editor for computers. Vi is the standard editor that is installed by default on any UNIX system. Because it uses very little resources, it is very fast even on old computers and slow network connections. Vi is very powerful, with almost unlimited features. You can use vi as an file editor by learning a few basic commands. Sooner or later, you may find yourself editing a file with vi.
Libranet uses vim, an extended version of vi, as the default vi editor.

sect1.title: The basics
sect1.para: Vi runs in two modes: command mode, and insert (edit) mode. When vi starts, it is running in command mode.

sect2.title: Inserting text
sect2.para: To begin inserting text in the command mode, press the <i> key, for insert. Once you have pressed <i> you will see the cursor change and you will see --INSERT-- in the lower left corner of the screen. You now can start inserting text.

sect2.title: Saving (writing) changes
sect2.para: To save changes you made to a file, you need to be in command mode. To leave insert mode and enter command mode, you press the <Esc> key.
